I am ſure I would not, for a thouſand guineas, that it happened in my houſe; and I pity his poor Lady, of all things.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: This is a maſter ſtroke, indeed, Mrs. Frankly. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why really, if this be the caſe, I do think his poor Lady is to be pitied—Why, man, the honey-moon is hardly over yet, and I declare that I was conſtant to my wife, for near a year after we were married—But then I was in love, mightily in love, d'ye ſee—However, I don't think that either you or I have any right to interfere in his Lordſhip's amours, Mrs. Frankly, and a forcible detainer is contrary to law—Beſides, I have a ſmall matter of buſineſs to confer with you upon myſelf, at preſent.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Which I will by no means interrupt, Governor, and heartily wiſh you may ſettle it to your mutual ſatisfaction. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
I ſhall be home to ſupper, my Lord. I
have beſpoke a couple of little plates to be dreſſed after our India faſhion. My Lady has ordered the reſt, I ſuppoſe. I make bold to hope, my dear little widow, that you underſtand ſomething of cookery—for they abſolutely know nothing of ſeaſoning their meat, in England. I have ſome excellent receipts of poor Bab's by me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: How could I be ſo weak a wretch, as to imagine I could retain Lord Seaton's affections. He is, alas! gone from me for ever. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: You ſeem mightily diſturbed, I think— I wonder ſhe does not ſay any thing of the five hundred pounds. (Aſide.) No bad news, I hope, from your lawyers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Here comes another of my plagues.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Your ſervant, Mr. Bull. Now, my little widow, ſpeak to Sammy, there—he'll make your mind eaſy, I believe. He is certain of your ſucceſs, and tells me that the ſuit will be determined, to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Trial put off, till next term.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Never the worſe for that, Maſter Bull. Stocks may riſe, by that time, perhaps. You did not ſell out—

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Before dinner.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: How unlucky! But, however, it don't much ſignify, as it happens, as I ſhall want that, and another five hundred, for Squeezem, this very night.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Money diſpoſed of to lawyers. Did not know of the delay, till it was expended. Won't refund. Muſt be refreſhed again, firſt day of term.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Refreſhed! I actually believe you invent words only to put me in a paſſion. This refreſhment has almoſt thrown me into a fever.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Don't be obſtinate—ſpeak to him, or we ſhall be undone, Maria. (Aſide to Mrs. Frankly.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: No matter—I care not what becomes of you, myſelf, or all the world.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Nay, prithee, don't take on ſo, neither— Though delays are dangerous, to be ſure, as well as mortifying.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Wants comfort, mightily.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: And ſhe ſhall have it, Sammy, eh! But, let's ſee—Why the term don't ſit till November next—That's a plaguy long day, to be ſure—I thought to have been married directly—and if one was certain that this ſame law ſuit, d'ye ſee, was quite a hollow thing—

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Quite hollow.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Say you ſo? Why then, if my pretty widow pleaſes, we'll be married to-morrow, and dine at the London Tavern, or the Crown and Anchor, or wherever elſe ſhe pleaſes—You ſhall have your choice, d'ye ſee—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: All places upon earth are equal now to me—for none can quiet my diſtracted mind.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: (To Bull.) Why I don't rightly underſtand that, now—Didn't ſhe whiſper ſomething about diſtractions? eh! There's no madneſs in the family, I hope.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Madneſs! No, no, no—Diſtracted with joy, on her wedding-day, that's all—Pretty compliment, if rightly taken—Has wit at her fingers end—Recover yourſelf, or we are ruined.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Why that is witty, to be ſure, but it did
not ſtrike me, I own, at firſt. (To Mrs. Frankly.) Well, but compoſe yourſelf, d'ye ſee, for too much joy may ſometimes be hurtful.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Mine will not be immoderate, Sir, I promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: That's very diſcreetly ſaid, now. I am impatient for to-morrow. I'll go directly to beſpeak the dinner, and get the licence ready. Come, Mr. Bull, you ſhall go with me. But won't your niece give me one kiſs?—

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: May command it.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: D'ye tell me ſo; by your leave then. (Kiſſes her.) Her breath ſmells like Otto of roſes. By the way you ſhall have a bottle of the beſt that ever was made in Perſia, to-morrow morning. The Great Mogul has not as good. But, come along, Maſter Bull, I have many matters, and money matters, to talk to you about; but thoſe little twinklers put every thing out of my head. I ſhall want a thouſand pounds for the good of the nation, this very night, d'ye ſee. I have promiſed to ſend it to Squeezem, and Ned Anderſon never yet broke his word; and that's a bold expreſſion for one of my age, let me tell you. I am not a man of words, but of deeds, my little widow, and I hope you'll like me the better, therefore—eh! and ſo adieu, My pretty, pretty Poll. (Singing.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: I am glad they are gone—I could not conquer my confuſion! Deteſted be the hour I tried the art to wear a ſmile upon my cheek, while rage and grief tear my diſtracted ſoul.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Lord, Madam! what a ſad buſtle has been here this afternoon; I am afraid we are all blown up with the Governor, as I hear he was by at ſome part of it!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Lucy, I am undone for ever! I have loſt Lord Seaton's heart, and all other miſery is equal to me.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I wiſh you had no other misfortune to complain of, Madam. Hearts are ſoon won, and ſoon loſt. It is not love, but money, that ſhould take up your thoughts at preſent. In ſhort, all your creditors are alarmed, and you had much better think of the only way you have to quiet them, by becoming the Governor's lawful wife immediately.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: I do not want your advice, but your pity, Lucy.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Pity! Charity begins at home, Madam; and for that matter, I think myſelf as much to be pitied as other people.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: (Pauſing.) Get me a pen and ink; I'll write to Lord Seaton directly.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: If you have loſt his heart, a pen and ink will hardly bring it back again; but they are on your table in the dreſſing room; and if I might adviſe, it would be, for the preſent, at leaſt, to drop a connection, which, by ruining you, may injure my own intereſts. (Careleſsly.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: And pray, Mrs. Lucy, how came your intereſts to be any way connected in this matter?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
Why really, Madam, to tell you the truth, I apprehend, that if any unlucky circumſtance
ſhould break off your match with the Governor, it would then be out of your power to reward my many long and faithful ſervices.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Inſolent wretch! needed there this addition to my misfortunes!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: People who bring on their own misfortunes, Madam—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Are to be inſulted by their ſervants, it ſeems—But I will no longer bear your inſolence.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Nor I your diſtreſſes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: My affability has been miſtaken, I find, or you had not dared to inſult me thus— But as for the extraordinary merits you boaſt of, I ſhall think it not the leaſt injuſtice to leave ſuch virtues to their own reward. Prepare your accounts inſtantly, nor dare appear before me again, but to give them in. Ungrateful woman! Exit.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
Prepare your accounts. Yes, that's eaſily done. I have them pretty well by heart already. I'll give them in, to-morrow morning, to the Governor, and leave you two to caſt them up together, at your next meeting. Ungrateful woman, too, I am called. 'Tis fine talking, truly, about gratitude, and ſuch ſtuff, becauſe one won't ſpend their whole life in poverty with her—and that I foreſee will be her fate, at laſt. In love with my Lord, forſooth! and every thing muſt be ſacrificed to that girliſh paſſion. Why, if the Governor ſhould marry her to-morrow, 'tis ten to one but ſhe'd be in the heighth of the mode in a week; in Doctor's Commons in a fortnight; and a beggar before the honey-moon was over. But I'll prevent that miſchief, at leaſt, by expoſing her to his Excellency; and if he is bent upon matrimony, right or wrong,
there are people who think me handſomer than my miſtreſs; and if he has but half as much ſenſe, as money, he may poſſibly be of the ſame opinion too. Exit.

sp.speaker: COLONEL.
sp.p: MY ſearch has hitherto been vain; but I have juſt now heard that my ſiſter Freeman is expected ſoon in town; and if female friendſhips are not, as Lord Seaton ſays, an empty name, ſhe will probably know ſomething of my dear Charlotte's ſituation or abode. My engagement here, for this evening, puts it out of my power to enquire about her, to-night; but to morrow early I ſhall call at her houſe—Mrs. Markam!

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: You are welcome to England, Sir, but am ſorry to acquaint you that my Lady happens to be ſo much indiſpoſed, at preſent, that ſhe muſt deny herſelf the pleaſure of ſeeing you, for this evening.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am extremely ſorry for your Lady's illneſs, Mrs. Markam. This ſudden attack alarms me for her.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p:
O, by no means ſudden, Sir. My Lady has been ill of the ſame diſorder, ever ſince ſhe has been married. I wonder, for my part, how ſhe has been able to bear it ſo patiently; but ſhe is convinced, at laſt, and I hope ſhe'll pluck up a
ſpirit now, and not ſuffer herſelf to be impoſed upon, any longer.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I do not underſtand you. She ſeemed to be in perfect health, at dinner.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Well, Sir, and if ſhe was, ſhe has had enough in conſcience to have made her ſick, ſince then. She'll believe me, another time, I fancy. I am not apt to be miſtaken, whatever ſhe may be. I am ſure it is a ſcandalous thing for him that has ſuch a charming Lady of his own, and has not been married quite two months yet—And that pretty demure Miſs too, that my Lady was ſo fond of—But I never liked her, for my part, and always ſaid that ſmooth water—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Prithee, Mrs. Markam, explain yourſelf— You alarm me, extremely.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: I beg your honour's pardon—I forgot that you were in love with Miſs Melville formerly, or to be ſure I would not have ſaid a word againſt her before you; but then I was ſo enraged with my Lord for ſlighting his good Lady, that I could not command myſelf—Though for certain it is no affair of mine, after all; and I muſt beg, Sir, that you would not mention any thing I have ſaid, for the world; for my Lady would never forgive me, if ſhe knew that I ſpoke of it to any one.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am on the rack. (Aſide.) The only way then to inſure my ſecrecy, Mrs. Markam, is by making me a thorough confidant; for as yet I do not comprehend what Miſs Melville has to do with either your Lady's illneſs, or your Lord's unkindneſs. She quitted this houſe, I have been informed, before they were married; and they have both aſſured me they have neither of them ſeen her, ſince.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Does my Lord ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: He moſt certainly did.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Why then great folks have a patent— I ſuppoſe; for as ſure as I ſtand here, my Lady detected his Lordſhip and Miſs Melville together, this very afternoon—And was that their firſt tête à tête, think you?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: By heaven, I cannot give credit to this ſtory—I ſhould ſtill think it impoſſible, though Lord Seaton and Miſs Melville themſelves were both to confeſs it.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir, I am frightened out of my wits—It mayn't be true, as you ſay, after all. I could bite my tongue off for being ſo nimble. I wiſh heartily I had been dumb.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: If you have idly ſlandered Miſs Melville, you deſerve to be ſo for life. But I will have this matter explained immediately—Where is Lord Seaton?

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: O dear, good Colonel, for heaven's ſake don't be in a paſſion—there might be no harm done, to be ſure—he was only kneeling at her feet, when my Lady happened to come into the room.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Inſidious, baſe diſſembler!

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p: Why to be ſure he has a diſſembling tongue, and every one thought that he was in love with my Lady, before he married her, except herſelf—But ſhe, it ſeems, had her ſuſpicions that he liked Miſs better, and that made my Lady ſo cold to her, that ſhe hardly opened her lips to her for a great while before ſhe left the houſe. (A rapping at the door.) Here's my Lord a coming, I fear.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I hope ſo.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.p:
O dear, merciful Colonel, have compaſſion, and don't betray me now. Conſider I am but a poor ſervant, Sir, and indeed Miſs Melville was always very kind to me; and if your honour
will but forgive me, this once, I promiſe never to ſpeak another word againſt her, while I have breath —But I muſt run, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And well you have rewarded her kindneſs. But when perſons of rank and education ſet an example of meanneſs and ingratitude, we are not to expect to meet with their oppoſite virtues, in an inferior claſs.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: O Charles, I am glad to meet you. I have a perfect novel of extraordinary incidents to communicate to you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And I am glad, my Lord, that we are met, and that you are in ſuch a communicative diſpoſition, as I have a queſtion to aſk you, that muſt be anſwered.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Muſt, Colonel!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, it muſt be reſolved—Where is Miſs Melville?

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: That queſtion, Colonel, neither muſt, nor can, be reſolved, by me—I know not where ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Can it be poſſible you ſhould be mean enough to attempt to ſcreen an act of perfidy and baſeneſs, beneath the flimſy ſubterfuge of falſehood! But 'twill not do, my Lord; we muſt not part, till you inform me where Miſs Melville is; and from her lips, which uſed to be the oracles of truth, I will learn all the reſt.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: You really aſtoniſh me, Sir, with a language as little becoming you to uſe, as for me to bear.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
The man who has deſerved ſuch language ought to bear it. Courage and falſehood never
dwelt together; and when the mind is ſo far debaſed, as to forge a tale to impoſe upon a friend, all pretence to bravery is but a jeſt—a madman's phrenzy, or a coward's rage.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: I can endure this inſolence, no longer. This roof is your protection, for the preſent, Sir; but quit it inſtantly, and let us quickly meet where the vile term you have now uſed, may light on him who moſt deſerves it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Unworthy as I think your Lordſhip's conduct, I cannot yet refuſe your appointment—To-morrow morning I ſhall call upon you—till then, farewel, my Lord. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: You ſhall find me ready, Sir. How was it poſſible for him to know that I had ſeen Miſs Melville? When I came in the ſervant told me my wife was ill, and had not ſeen the Colonel— She could not, therefore, nay, ſhe would not, tell him—But it matters not, at preſent, who informed him. I never meant to injure him. I did not know of his paſſion for Charlotte, till after I was married; and had I, on his return, acknowledged each circumſtance that ever paſſed between us, he could not have condemned me. How weak and culpable is want of frankneſs? This alone has involved me in all my difficulties.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: From Mrs. Frankly, my Lord. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p:
(Reads.)
Notwithſtanding inhumanity, unkind treatment of me—fondneſs triumphed—ſtill weak enough—Poſſibly hazard— breaking off—advantageous match—A man I deteſt—But what is worldly intereſt, &c.
Mary Frankly.
Deſpicable, yet unhappy woman! The artful meanneſs of her conduct, this evening, has ſunk her below my pity. This marriage that ſhe hints at, is thrown out merely to draw me to her lure—But 'tis in vain, for I ſhall never ſee, or think of her, again. Indeed I have ſomething more material to take up my thoughts, at preſent—This haſty conduct of Ramſay's diſtreſſes me extremely—But 'tis firſt neceſſary that I ſhould clear Miſs Melville's conduct to my wife—They muſt be mutual ſufferers by the continuance of Lady Seaton's miſtake; and ſhe, at leaſt, deſerves all my endeavours to reſtore her peace. Though I cannot account for her following me to Mrs. Frankly's this evening. But grant it were a fault, 'tis her firſt to me, and mine I confeſs to have been manifold againſt her—Who's there?

Aſk Markam if her Lady be in her dreſſing-room, and let her know that I deſire to ſpeak with her. [Exit Waters.] In what different points of view do the ſame objects preſent themſelves, at different times, before us! The ſeriouſneſs of my preſent ſituation has removed the veil which the falſe notions and looſe manners of the preſent world had ſpread over my thoughts and actions. I ſee now the impropriety, nay, the inhumanity, of my whole conduct to Lady Seaton, and wiſh, though perhaps too late, that it may yet be in my power to make her every atonement.
You ſeem alarmed, Madam; but lay aſide your fears—You have nothing to apprehend.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: The conſciouſneſs, my Lord, of having offended you, though moſt inadvertently, muſt certainly render me unhappy.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: The extraordinary ſtep you took this evening, Madam, appears to be but little conſiſtent with the delicacy of the ſentiment you now expreſs.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: If you will condeſcend to hear my motives for it, my Lord, you will not judge ſo hardly of me. I then thought Miſs Melville innocent—

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: And ſo, by heaven, ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I repeat it; and though to ſupport my aſſertion, I ſhall be obliged to accuſe myſelf, yet will I do her merit the juſtice it deſerves. On my return from Italy, at the ſame moment I beheld ye both—

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: Stop there, my Lord—too well, alas! I know who then won the preference in your affections.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Paſſion is involuntary, Madam; but I had hopes that reaſon, which directed my addreſſes to you, would have conquered that partiality.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: Impoſſible, my Lord, I fear; and bluſhing own, that though I perceived your attachment to my rival, I yet nouriſhed in my breaſt the ſame to you—By vain ſelf-love miſled, I fondly thought I might perhaps inſpire the tenderneſs I felt—My weakneſs has been puniſhed as it ought!

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: You judge yourſelf too ſeverely, Madam—'Tis I alone am culpable.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: We both deceived ourſelves, my Lord, and both have been to blame.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p:
I would not wiſh, Madam, to involve you in my errors, and am ſincerely ſorry you ſhould have ſuffered by them—Let me now proceed—
After ſome unſucceſsful ſtruggles with myſelf, I at length determined to confeſs my prepoſſeſſion for Miſs Melville, and break off the treaty with you— I wrote to her, accordingly, on the ſubject—Her anſwer was conſiſtent with that worth which dignifies her whole conduct. She owned ingenuouſly that her heart had been preingaged, but alſo generouſly aſſured me, that were it perfectly free, ſhe could never have availed herſelf of my preference in her favour, to your prejudice.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: Generous, charming girl! how have I injured her!

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: I have reaſon to believe that ſhe left this houſe, in hopes her abſence might efface my paſſion, and ſuffer your beauty and merits, Madam, to produce the effect they muſt naturally have had upon a diſengaged heart. From that moment, till this evening, and that by accident merely, I declare I never ſaw or heard from her; and was, at that inſtant, only intreating her return to you again. If therefore you have conceived one doubt to her diſhonour, baniſh it for ever from your mind.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: I never had a doubt, my Lord, of Charlotte's worth, nor was it jealouſy, but friendſhip, that brought me to be a witneſs of that ſcene which firſt diſturbed my confidence in her—But you have now reſtored it, and if I knew where to direct my courſe, I would this moment fly to intreat her pardon, as I do yours; for I have injured you beyond the hope of an atonement—'Twas ſelfiſh vanity inſpired the cruel wiſh of being yours, without the power of paying back the happineſs I received.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p:
Nay, Madam, do not ſpeak ſo humbly—The polite attentions which I paid you, joined to your own perſonal charms and merits, might,
without vanity, have made you think that you poſſeſſed my love; whilſt I, falſe to your happineſs, as well as to my own, knew but too well I had not then a heart to give.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: In vain, my Lord, you kindly ſtrive to ſet my mind at peace, and reconcile me to an error that has been fatal to us both, I fear.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: I am too ſenſible how far I have wronged you, to bear this generous conteſt; but may I hope the frankneſs I have ſhewn, in thus diſcovering to you the weakneſs of my conduct, will at leaſt aſſure you of my confidence and eſteem.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: I aſk no more, my Lord, and ſhall ever ſtudy to deſerve them.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: The kindneſs and condeſcenſion of that ſpeech, Lady Seaton, merits much more, and has awaked my tenderneſs—But is that worthy your acceptance, now?

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: The world were well exchanged for ſuch a treaſure!

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Accept then, thou moſt deſerving of thy ſex, a heart more ſurely thine, than if it had firſt been led to you by paſſion only, for that is liable to change; but kindneſs and worth, like yours, muſt naturally inſpire unfading love.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: My tears alone can ſpeak my joy! my gratitude!

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Thus let me wipe away the precious drops, and with them all remembrance of my paſt follies. (Embraces her.)

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Why, hey dey, what wind blows now! but no matter, this at leaſt is as it ſhould be, and
juſt ſo I hope little ſpouſey and I will ſpend our time together. I have a buſineſs of conſequence to communicate to your Lordſhip—I do all above board, d'ye ſee, and as I thought you were dull and alone, I came up to diſcourſe you a little—I am glad to ſee you recovered, niece, they told me you were ſick, and kept your chamber.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: I am much better, Sir, and now may truly ſay that I am well and happy.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: And I am truly glad of both, my dear niece.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: (To Lady Seaton.) Can it be poſſible, my dear, that, generous as your nature is, a woman can ſincerely pardon a preference once ſhewn to another?

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: The doubt's unkind—but aſk yourſelf, my Lord, Can there be any thing in nature more pleaſing to a generous mind, than to have ſomething to forgive?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why this is downright making love, my Lord, and renders me the more impatient to talk of my own affairs, d'ye ſee.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Retire, my dear, and reſt aſſured that all my future life ſhall be devoted to the continuance of our preſent happineſs.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: Your kind intentions have ſecured its permanence, and made my bliſs complete. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: (Lord Seaton looking after her.) How little do we foreſee the evils that await us! the apprehenſions of what that amiable woman may have yet to ſuffer, on my account, diſturb me much.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Why for that matter, my Lord, I am a little diſturbed myſelf, d'ye ſee, or elſe I would not have troubled you—You muſt know then, that I am going to be married out of hand, directly, and
my friend Bull, who was to have given away the bride, writes me word that he can't attend my wedding—but if your Lordſhip will be ſo good to ſupply his place, d'ye ſee—

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: I heartily wiſh you joy, Governor, and will readily accept the office; but pray who is our aunt to be?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: One that you have ſeen, very lately, my Lord, but you don't know half her good qualities, perhaps; ſhe is the modeſteſt, moſt reſerved little rogue—and a man, at my time of life, you know, and in theſe times too, has no buſineſs with a fine gay flaunting Lady, d'ye ſee.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Not much, truly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: No, no, Ned Anderſon is no ſuch ſimpleton! I have choſen a ſober, diſcreet, young creature, very handſome withal—that will mind family matters, and be proud of her huſband's company, d'ye ſee—Can't you gueſs, now, my Lord? there are but few, in theſe days, that can anſwer ſuch a deſcription, I fancy —

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Very few, I believe, Governor, and I happen to be wholly unacquainted with any of that ſmall number.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why then not to puzzle you farther, my Lord, the firſt letter of her name is Frankly—

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Frankly!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why yes, my Lord, the pretty widow, at whoſe houſe we happened to meet, this evening —ſhe was mightily concerned for my niece, I aſſure you; for ſhe is very ſtrict, and was greatly out of ſorts at your behaviour. And by the way you ought to be a little more cautious in your conduct, and not expoſe yourſelf, by purſuing a girl into a ſtrange houſe, d'ye ſee—

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: I am much obliged to you for your advice, Sir. But pray will you give me leave to aſk you by what means you became acquainted with this ſame paragon of virtue?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why my good friend, honeſt Sam. Bull, the broker, having in the courſe of our buſineſs together, conceived a particular regard for me, introduced me to his niece, ſome time ago—ſhe has a jointure of ſix hundred per annum, and he was plaguily afraid that ſome young fop might run away with her, and uſe her ill; he therefore recommended me as one that would be a kind of a father to her, d'ye ſee—

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Yes, that I do ſee, very plainly, indeed—But pray is your good friend Mr. Bull a broker for marriages, as well as ſtocks, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: No, no, my Lord, he made no matter of buſineſs of it, in the leaſt; for tho' he underſtands making a bargain as well as any man in the Alley, he never once talked of a ſettlement—all, all is left to my own honour—but he knows his man, that's pretty plain, I think—

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Very apparent, truly.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Do you think your Lordſhip can be ready to attend upon us to church by nine, to-morrow morning?

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: To-morrow, Governor!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Yes, to-morrow is to be the happy day, nephew.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: As circumſtances are drawing ſo near a concluſion, Sir, I will be free enough to tell you, that you muſt not think of Mrs. Frankly, for a wife.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Why that is frank and free enough, to be ſure, my Lord; but I muſt have ſome better reaſon than a mere ipſe dixit, as Nicholas calls it. I
have always been a man of honour, to the ladies, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: I approve your chivalry, Governor, but with this reſerve, that you are ſure your Ladies be alſo Ladies of honour, on their part; leſt your knight-errantry ſhould be diſhonoured by your galantry; and as it is happily not yet too late, I may venture to tell you that your preſent Dulcinea is totally devoid of ſuch a character.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Not too late! Ay, truly, but it is, tho', for I have not even ſo much as an acknowledgment under her hand, for five hundred pounds I lent her, this very morning, to fee her lawyers; and I gave her a pair of ear-rings, not a month ago, that coſt me five hundred pounds more. But if ſhe has no honour, 'tis well ſhe has ſome land, at leaſt. Bull aſſures me that her jointure is a good ſix hundred, per annum.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: What! upon his eſtate, Governor?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I never heard he had one.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Nor I either, I promiſe you; and I rather doubt his having a foot of ground to ſtand upon, in the Alley, much longer.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Don't ſay ſo, my Lord; you'll break my heart. If Bull has waddled out a lame duck, I may be an undone man, for aught I ſee.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Matters may not be ſo bad as you apprehend; but at any rate I think you have reaſon to rejoice at having eſcaped being Mrs. Frankly's dupe, at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Rejoice! at what? that I have been deceived and diſappointed in the woman I had ſet my heart upon, when it is too late in life to think of mending myſelf elſewhere. But I'll have my money and my jewels from her, if they are to be had, d'ye ſee, before we part.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: You'll find it rather a difficult matter, I fancy, to recover your property out of ſuch hands; but I wiſh you ſucceſs, and a good night, with all my heart, Governor. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: A good night! fine talking, truly, after you have broke my reſt. I don't believe I ſhall be able to get a wink of ſleep, this month to come. I think I am even more diſturbed, now, than when my poor Bab died, and I remember that I lay awake, that night, almoſt three hours, tho' I had not loſt a farthing, neither.

sp.speaker: Pomp.
sp.p: A young Lady deſires to ſee you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: What! a young Lady, did you ſay?

sp.speaker: Pomp.
sp.p: Here ſhe is herſelf, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: So, Mrs. Lucy, what! does your miſtreſs want another five hundred, to refreſh her lawyers, to-morrow, and has ſent you to wheedle me out of it? Eh!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No really, Sir, I am not the perſon you take me for. I would ſcorn to join in impoſing on ſo worthy a gentleman, as your Excellency.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Worthy me no worthies, Mrs. Abigail, it won't do, I can tell you—ſhe has miſtaken her man, d'ye ſee—I am not ſo eaſily impoſed upon as ſhe may imagine.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I am ſure, Sir, it has broke my heart, to ſee how you have been cheated and deceived, both by Mr. Bull and Mrs. Frankly.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
You acknowledge it, then. But I'll ſhew them the difference immediately, and Bull may look
out for ſome fitter dupe to repair the honour and fortune of his family, by marrying his niece.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: His niece! why that, indeed, ſounds well, Sir—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why, is not Bull her uncle, girl?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No more related to her, Sir, than you are. The very jewels you gave her, Sir, are gone, paſt redemption. Sold, Sir, to ſupply her uncle's neceſſities, and will never more be heard of, believe me.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I am ſtruck dumb with amazement! But, if Bull be not her uncle, why ſhould ſhe beſtow him her jewels, d'ye ſee?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, there may be cloſer connections, than relations, I ſuppoſe, in the world.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I ſhall be petrified! Why he is not her galant, ſure, is he?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I ſcorn to ſpeak ſcandal, Sir; but if he be, he is not her only one, I can aſſure you; for Lord Seaton is another—Tho' the paſſion happens unluckily to be all on the wrong ſide there, I can anſwer for it—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: My hair ſtands an end at her wickedneſs! As for you, girl, there take my purſe, as a reward for your honeſty, d'ye ſee—but never let me ſee you, or any thing that belongs to your miſtreſs, more.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: So then, the beſt part of my ſcheme is diſappointed, I find—I don't believe that he has even looked at me. (Aſide). I thank your Excellency, and wiſh you a good night, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Good-bye to ye. Good-bye to ye. Get you out. Get you out. (Puſhing her off.) In love with Lord Seaton! O the devil, the devil! what now in nature can make people ſuch rogues! one
hears, every day, here, of ſuch pranks as would taint the very air of India, and breed a peſtilence there. I'll go back, I'll go back again, in the firſt ſhip that ſails, and ſpend the remainder of my life among men whoſe words are bonds, and where the ties of honour require no laws to bind them—But firſt I'll go maul my happy—I'll break her night's reſt, for her, and her heart too, if I can. The intriguing gipſey! Exit.

div.head: ACT V.

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR.
sp.p: I HAVE had a deviliſh bad night of it. If I had vented my rage, I might have got ſome ſleep, perhaps—but ſhe was in bed, and would not ſee me, forſooth.—Plaguy modeſt, to be ſure. But I'll make bold to break her morning ſlumbers. I'll rouſe her, that I will. Get me my breakfaſt, quickly—There's no good in faſting, d'ye ſee— Diſpatch, I ſay, or I ſhall go without it—My rage will burſt me—

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I grieve to ſee your Excellency ſo much inflated with choler—but I obey. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why, how now, Mr. Squeezem!

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: O, Sir, you have made a fine hand of your affairs, with your boaſted punctuality—We have no bonds, in India, forſooth. Commend me to the perſons who are not aſhamed to ſet their names to a piece of ſtamped paper. They are the men to do buſineſs with.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Why, what can be the meaning of all this! Did not Bull carry you the money, laſt night?
And were you not to ſet out with the ſun, this morning?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: No, really, Sir, Mr. Bull did not bring me a farthing; but I believe he has carried that, and himſelf off together, by the light of the moon; for he was not to be found at his own houſe, at day-break, when I called there; and I fancy that neither ſun or moon will ever ſee him in England again.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: So then 'tis pretty plain that I have been completely gulled, jilted, bulled and beared, by a profeſſing ſcoundrel and a pretty face—

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: What ſignifies all this, to your ſeat in the houſe? Honours, Sir, don't ſpring up like muſhrooms, in a night—They are not to be had when, where, and how you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: No, Sir, nothing is to be had as I pleaſe. —All's loſt—all's gone—I ſee it—I know it—I'm an object of pity, Mr. Squeezem. So if you'l pleaſe to refund me the thouſand I advanced to you—

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Why ſurely, Sir, you are not in earneſt. Refund, quotha! Why, Sir, it was all gone, ſwallowed, eaten and drank up, in one day. Electioneering is your only true ſinking fund, Governor. Potwallopers refund!

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Sir, your Excellency's meal is prepared within.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Go eat it then—I have no appetite left.— Potwalloppers! a thouſand pounds potwalloped, in a day! impoſſible! I'll cram them with turtle, 'till they burſt, d'ye ſee, and defy them to do it.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: It is reported that Anthony and Cleopatra expended, at one ſupper—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Choke them with their ſupper, impertinent—I ſhall run mad, with vexation. What! a thouſand pounds in a day, and not to have either my money, or myſelf returned, after all!

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, how impatiently you talk! Why many, and many an honeſt gentleman has ſpent ten thouſand, in the ſame way, and had no more for his money, than you have.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Get out of my ſight, I adviſe you, while I can yet command my temper. A thouſand pounds at a meal!

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: As you ſeem a little indiſpoſed, at preſent, Sir, I ſhall take your advice, and retire; but if any other ſnug, convenient ſeat ſhould offer, in futuro, Sir, you may freely command the ſervices of your moſt obedient, Bartholomew Squeezem.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: You and your diſſervices may go to the vengeance together. I have got enough of electioning, and of courting too, for life, I think. I'll ſee Mrs. Frankly, this inſtant, and have juſtice on that villain Bull, if 'tis to be had in the land. Was there ever ſo unfortunate a man as I am! diſappointed in every thing—plundered by every body! What a pack of troubles have I brought upon myſelf, without deſigning the leaſt manner of miſchief to any one alive! Exit.

div.p:
Bull's abſconding, and Lucy's deſerting me, in ſo critical a ſituation, have happened moſt unluckily.
What excuſe can I make, for Bull's abſence, to the Governor? He was here late, laſt night, and raving at being refuſed admittance▪ Fear of detection, what a curſe art thou! O could the young and artleſs mind but know the agonies that dwell with guilt, it would prefer the humbleſt lot with peace, to all that ſplendid vice can e'er beſtow.—But what have I to do with ſuch reflections, now! No reply yet from Seaton—his cold unkindneſs ſtabs me to the heart—My dear Governor—
div.stage: Enter the GOVERNOR, in a paſſion.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Thou worſe than a vulture, or a kite— thou cruelleſt, and moſt ungrateful of women! I know not where to begin, nor in what language to ſpeak of you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: (What can this mean! Lucy has betrayed me, I fear. Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I am thoroughly acquainted with your arts, I know all your hiſtory at full length, d'ye ſee.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: I hope it has entertained you, Sir, for you ſeem to be much engaged with it.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Don't offer to interrupt me—Let me ſpeak, I ſay. That villain Bull, that fellow that paſſed for your uncle, is no more related to you than the Great Mogul. He is your galant, it ſeems, and you meant to marry me, merely to make his fortune.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Mr. Bull of all creatures, my galant! This is too ridiculous, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
'Tis true, for all that, as honeſt Lucy has aſſured me—and the very jewels I gave you,
nay, perhaps, the money I advanced to ſee your lawyers, ungenerous woman, have been all ſacrificed to him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Lucy! and ſo honeſt Mrs. Lucy is your informer, Sir! I give you joy of your authority.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Don't anſwer me, I ſay, thou harpy—I have not brought half my charges againſt you, yet.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: I ſhall not attempt to anſwer you, indeed, Sir, as you really appear to be quite out of your reaſon, at preſent, and there is no arguing with a madman.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: If I am mad, 'tis you that have made me ſo—but your inſolence ſhall not defend you. I will expoſe you and your good uncle Bull, to the whole world. I won't confine myſelf to one quarter of it—all India ſhall know how you have uſed me. Where are the ear-rings I gave you? Where are my jewels, I ſay? ſhew them to me, this inſtant. I inſiſt upon ſeeing them, at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: How is that poſſible, pray, if I have already given them to Mr. Bull?—Delirious!

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Her aſſurance amazes me—I thought ſhe would have fallen at my feet and implored my pardon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: No, really, Sir—injured innocence has a right to reſent—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Injured innocence!—that word has almoſt choked me—This is too much—Then, Madam Injured Innocence, I have accuſed you wrongfully, it ſeems—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: So you may poſſibly find, Sir, when perhaps it may be too late to repent of it.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: And why the plague don't you juſtify yourſelf then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: So I would, Sir, if you were in a condition to hear reaſon.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Well, well—ſpeak—ſpeak freely.—I am perfectly cool—quite calm, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Hear me, then. All this rage of yours proceeds from Lucy's having trumped up a falſe ſtory—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: A falſe ſtory! Hell and the furies! then prove it ſo, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Don't ſwear, Sir—remember you are perfectly cool—quite calm, you know.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Well, well, I am ſo, I had forgot—Go on, Madam, now, without interruption.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Then firſt, Sir, give me leave to aſk you if you are acquainted with the reaſon of Lucy's quitting my ſervice?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, becauſe ſhe could not bear to be a witneſs of your impoſing on me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Juſt the reverſe, Sir—I turned her out of my houſe, laſt night, for abuſing you, ungenerous as you are.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Abuſing me! Why, what could the minx find to ſay againſt me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: How can you think, ſaid ſhe, of burying your youth, beauty, and fortune, in the arms of your grandfather! when there are ſo many—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Grandfather! confound the jade.—Let me hear no more of her impertinence, but come to the point, Madam; Where is your uncle, and where are my diamonds, d'ye ſee?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p:
Mr. Bull, Sir, is gone into Wiltſhire, to bring up a witneſs to prove my dear Mr. Frankly's laſt will—and as to the diamonds, Sir,
Lucy, you ſay, has given you a full account of them.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and a receipt in full, too, Madam—your pretended uncle has carried them into Wiltſhire to bribe your evidence, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Mr. Bull has them, then! mighty well, Sir. And if I was to produce them now, what would you ſay, then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Say! why really in ſuch a caſe, Madam, I ſhould ſay—hang me, if I know what I ſhould ſay—but 'tis abſolutely impoſſible—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p:
Then not to ſatisfy, but to ſhock you, look there—
(opening a caſket. He ſtarts.)— Now take them back again, Sir, for as I prized them more as a token, than a gift, they have loſt their value with your unkindneſs. (Weeps.)

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I am confounded! I am dead! the very jewels I gave her, that's certain! That vile jade Lucy! I ſee you are innocent, Madam, and muſt implore your pardon for having doubted it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: You ought not to have doubted it, Sir, nor have ventured to inſult a woman of honour upon the teſtimony of a wretch, whom common ſenſe might have informed you I ſhould not have diſcarded, had it been in her power to have hurt me.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why to be ſure I might have thought of that, Madam, but you can't conceive what a pack of plauſible lies ſhe told me.—She ſaid you were in love too with Lord Seaton, who deſpiſed you— nay his Lordſhip ſpoke to your diſadvantage himſelf, alſo, and firſt cautioned me againſt marrying you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p:
But ſurely now any perſon of common ſenſe, Sir, would have conſidered his endeavour to prevent it, as a proof rather of love,
than of hate—I ſoon perceived he had gained Lucy over to his intereſt, which was the chief reaſon of my diſcharging her; in revenge for which ſhe invented all thoſe abominable ſtories, and you were weak enough to believe them.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I have been weak enough, to be ſure; but you ſhall find now that I am perfectly ſatiſfied.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: You allow then, that you have been in the wrong, Sir—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: And that you have been duped by a woman—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Shamefully—I ſee it, now—I feel it— Yes, yes, I have been duped, indeed, with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: And you really do repent of your credulity.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Repent! ſhall hang myſelf if you do not forgive me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p: Well, well, then, I do forgive you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: And I aſk your pardon, again and again —So now let us kiſs and friends—kiſs and friends, for life, d'ye ſee. I ſhall think every minute an age 'till we are one—we'll be married, this very day. Let's loſe no time, d'ye ſee. I'll ſtep home and bring Nicholas, directly, to give you away, and do you run in and prepare, ſo that there may be no waiting when we call on you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Frank.
sp.p:
You treſpaſs on my fondneſs, which pleads your cauſe ſo ſtrongly; for had you leſs love, you would have had leſs jealouſy; and the exceſs of one ſhould ever atone for the vio
••• ce of the other. And ſo I ſhall be ready to attend you, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why that's very good-natured, and very true, too. Yes, indeed, I do love her monſtrouſly, or I ſhould not have been ſo jealous. But for all this I ſhall diſcourſe my Lord Seaton a little, before I am married; for I neither can, nor will be ſatisfied, till I have made him recant his calumny. Exit.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
The hurry and agitation I paſſed thro', yeſterday evening, have diſcompoſed my ſpirits ſo much that I find it impoſſible to reſt. Mrs. Freeman is not yet up, ſo that I have ſufficient leiſure to reflect on the extraordinary adventures of yeſterday, which I confeſs appear to me, now, more like a viſion than a fact. I am impatient till all this miſtery is explained, that I may have an opportunity of clearing my conduct to my amiable friend. If the weight only of an imputed crime be ſo hard to bear, what a burden muſt real guilt be! Lord Seaton ſaid ſomething, I think, of Colonel Ramſay. I dare not flatter my hopes about his arrival, as Mrs. Freeman knows nothing of it yet. But ſee, beyond a doubt my wiſhes are accompliſhed—
Enter Colonel RAMSAY. You are welcome to England, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
I have been ſo long abſent, Madam, that I own myſelf rather ſurprized at your recollection of a perſon whom I hoped, for your own ſake,
you had totally forgotten; and you muſt pardon me if I alſo add that my wonder is a good deal increaſed, by ſeeing you at preſent in Mrs. Freeman's houſe.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: What can this mean! Surely 'tis you, Sir, who have forgotten both yourſelf and me, or after two tedious years of abſence it were not poſſible we ſhould meet thus.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I fancy, Madam, that the abſence of an injured lover does not appear tedious to thoſe who enjoy the preſence of a favoured one. Lord Seaton, Madam, has ſufficiently conſoled you for my loſs.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Lord Seaton!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You ſeem ſurprized; but I am too well informed of your connection. However, Madam, I did not mean to upbraid, or intrude upon you, now. I came here only to ſee my ſiſter, and have but a ſhort time to ſpare to her, from a very particular and preſſing engagement.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Be your engagements what they may, Sir, I have a right to expect you ſhould explain the meaning of your preſent conduct towards me, as far at leaſt as it reſpects my character.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You ſpeak, Madam, as if you thought you ſtill retained the power you once had over me; but you have forfeited it, and I am no longer now the dupe of my own weakneſs, or of your deceit.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: O Ramſay, how have I deſerved this treatment?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
(I cannot bear her tears. Aſide.) I wiſh not, Madam, to offend or wound you—you are miſtreſs of your own actions, and all I ſhall further ſay, upon this ſubject, is, that had your new engagement
been more for your own honour, your perfidy might have been more pardonable to one who reſpected your character, as much as he admired your perſon.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I do not comprehend you, Sir. What engagements have I entered into, inconſiſtent with that preference I had too haſtily, I fear, confeſſed for you?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: The ties of hearts like mine are formed by honour only, Madam, nor could I ever take advantage of a woman's fondneſs to hurt her innocence, or wound her fame. Lord Seaton is a more modern kind of lover, Madam.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Lord Seaton again! What can you mean by him? Is he not married, Sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: For his unhappy lady's ſake, as well as yours, I would he were not. The woman I once loved might then have had ſome excuſe.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I can ſuſtain this injury no longer—Have you not known me from my earlieſt youth?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No, Madam, 'tis plain I did not. My fond imagination had indeed conceived a fair idea from Miſs Melville's form—a heart replete with honour, love and conſtancy! virtues too ſeldom found in your frail ſex, and it was vanity in me to hope I ſhould engroſs ſo rare a treaſure.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: What have I done to forfeit your opinion? But I will condeſcend to waive the pride of injured virtue, and tell you, Sir, that you are much deceived.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I have been ſo, I own, but the delirium's fled. My time is precious, now—I came hither on other purpoſe, Madam, and neither thought, or wiſhed to have met you here.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Can it be poſſible the time ſhould come, when Ramſay ſhould not wiſh to ſee me!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Too many hours have I, alas, devoted to the fond impatience of ſeeing her I loved.—'Twas the reward I promiſed to myſelf, for toil, for danger, for the ſtill greater pangs of abſence—and how have you repaid my anxious hope!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: If the moſt conſtant, unabated tenderneſs and eſteem could have repaid the ſufferings you pretend, I ſhould not now be deemed your debtor; nor would a lover, ſuch as you would ſeem, have liſtened to a tale invented by ſome fiend to blaſt my honour. O Ramſay! 'tis now, alas, too plain, you never loved.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: (I know not what to think—ſhe ſpeaks with confidence, and looks with innocence—yet Lady Seaton ſurely could not invent a falſhood. Perhaps I have been too raſh; and yet I have not time to repair my error, now. My honour is elſewhere too far engaged, at preſent, and the time draws near. Aſide.) If ever we ſhould meet again, Miſs Melville, you will be then convinced that I have loved.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: What do you ſay? If ever we ſhould meet! Do not diſtract me, Sir—you muſt not leave me till this riddle is explained, and you convinced both of my truth and love.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You muſt excuſe me, Madam, for the preſent. Tho' 'tis a ſubject of the deareſt import, I cannot now attend the explication. (Going.)

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Lord Seaton, Madam. Exit.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Lord Seaton! What can his viſit mean?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: O, fair diſſembler! my doubts are all explained.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: I come, Madam, to make my apology for having been, tho' inadvertently, the cauſe of any anxiety or diſtreſs to you.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lord, I know not how I have deſerved it, but you have been the ſource of moſt mortifying difficulties and diſtreſſes to me; but ſurely you will now be candid and generous enough to undeceive this gentleman, my friend—I know not what to ſtile him—Colonel Ramſay, with regard to me.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: O ſpare yourſelf and him the trouble, Madam; you are miſtaken, I am not deceived; I know Lord Seaton well, and know Miſs Melville, too.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Blind and ungrateful as you are to love and friendſhip, yet for Miſs Melville's ſake—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: O, Sir, I doubt not but, for her dear ſake, your Lordſhip may generouſly condeſcend to vouch her honour, with the loſs of yours. (But, my Lord, you know there is another mode of ſatisfying me. Aſide to Lord Seaton.)

div.stage: Enter Lady SEATON, who runs to Miſs Melville, and embraces her.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: My dear, my injured Charlotte, I have not words to atone the wrong I have done you, but hope in Colonel Ramſay to obtain an advocate more powerful than myſelf, for your forgiveneſs.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: (This ſurely muſt be illuſion all! my feet are rooted to the ſpot I ſtand upon with wonder! Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: My dear Lady Seaton, this is too good, too condeſcending, and too kind! I meant to have gone to you.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: No, my friend, nothing can be too much from one who has injured innocence and worth like yours by doubting of your virtue, for a moment.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I cannot comprehend this miſtery—it is impoſſible that you ſhould wrong me. Some ſpell has ſurely been caſt round me, for Ramſay too has doubted of my truth and love.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: I, only I, who formed the charm, can break it. (My weak unjuſt ſuſpicions have betrayed you into error; your cenſure and reſentment therefore ſhould light on me alone. To the Colonel.)

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I am perplexed—What can all this mean?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: It means, my Charlotte, that my too haſty credulity has hurried me into a fault; which I can never hope you ſhould forgive, the ſuſpecting truth and virtue ſuch as yours.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: To doubt of pardon, on repentance, aggravates the crime; for who that pretends not to perfection in themſelves, ſhall dare to be implacable to another's ſailings. But ſtill I am in the dark and on the rack, to know how all this ſtrange confuſion has been conjured up.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: It aroſe intirely from my indiſcretion in letting drop to Markam my having met you at Mrs. Frankly's. She happened to ſee the Colonel immediately after, and informed him of all, and perhaps more than ſhe knew.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: At Mrs. Frankly's!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Yes, at Mrs. Frankly's. Take care, Colonel; relapſes are dangerous to ſuſceptible conſtitutions—but I ſhall at more leiſure account to you for ſo extraordinary an incident.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And I ſhall moſt patiently wait 'till you think proper to gratify merely my curioſity, in that particular.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: But mine is not to be ſatisfied, 'till I know how Lady Seaton ſhould come there.

sp.speaker: Lady Sea.
sp.p: And I am ready to indulge you.— Unhappy at your abſence, my dear Charlotte, I ordered my ſervant to make every poſſible inquiry to find you out.—He ſaw you, by chance, going into Mrs. Frankly's, and was informed you lived there. I immediately flew to requeſt your company, in hopes of agreeably ſurpriſing both you and the Colonel with an unexpected interview, at my houſe. You know the unhappy miſtake occaſioned then by Mrs. Frankly's behaviour, for which I again aſk both my Lord's pardon, and yours.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: The nobleneſs of your behaviour, upon that occaſion, my dear, has fully entitled you to the warmeſt gratitude of every perſon preſent, tho' you yet know not how highly meritorious your conduct has been, to us all.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I bluſh to think how I have injured your Lordſhip, by my raſhneſs, and here throw myſelf on your generoſity for forgiveneſs.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: You ſhall not ſtoop to aſk it, Colonel—forgiveneſs we beſtow upon our enemies— but we are now, and ever ſhall be friends.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: A gentleman ſeeing your Lordſhip's carriage at the door, inquired if you were here, and deſires to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: I ſhall attend him. [Exit Servant.] By the degree of familiarity he uſes, I fancy it muſt be the Governor.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: If it be, my Lord, pray deſire him to walk up.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: You ſee, Madam, he introduces himſelf without a gentleman-uſher.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I have been at your houſe, to look for you, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Well, Governor, and now you have found me, what are your commands?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why, my Lord, I have both queſtions and commands to propoſe to you, d'ye ſee, tho' I think you have been more inclined to a game of croſs-purpoſes, than any thing elſe, lately. But in plain Engliſh, I think you have behaved very ungenerouſly in this affair of my marriage, let me tell you.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: His marriage! bleſs us, with whom?

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Your charge is ſevere, Governor; but, prithee, explain yourſelf, for at preſent I don't underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
I ſhall make it plain enough, I warrant you—I mean, my Lord, that you have traduced
the character of a woman, whoſe honour I am bound to ſupport, by every principle of a man, and I never yet put up with an affront, nor ever will, d'ye ſee.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Spoken like a champion, ſtout and ſtrong, Governor.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I don't mean to act the bravo, my Lord, tho' I have faced a Nabob, at the head of his forces, before now; but all I deſire of you, at preſent, is, that as a man of honour you will come with me and aſk Mrs. Frankly's pardon, before we go to church together.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Indeed, Governor, you muſt excuſe me from going through ſuch a ceremony, and alſo for endeavouring to prevent your going through a more ſerious one, with a woman who is—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Don't venture to ſay a word againſt her beauty, or her virtue, my Lord, or I may not be able to command myſelf, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: The goodneſs and generoſity of your own heart, Governor, render you too liable to impoſition. 'Tis the nature of man to impute their own principles to others, be they good or bad.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Why, I am not apt to be ſuſpicious, that's certain; and when I met you at my pretty widow's, yeſterday evening, I little thought that we had been rivals, d'ye ſee.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: To convince you, Sir, as well as the reſt of this company, that I have no farther deſigns upon that lady, I here reſign into your hands the laſt favour I received from hers. Read that, Governor. (Gives him Mrs. Frankly's letter.)

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
(Putting on his ſpectacles.) Hey day!— What's this! a billet to you! She has been very nimble in ſending it, truly.—I thought I had made
tolerable haſte in finding you, myſelf; but my legs are none of the beſt, to be ſure. (Opens the letter, and reads.) Notwithſtanding the inhumanity of your unkind treatment of me. You ſee, my Lord, ſhe reſents your behaviour, mightily. My fondneſs has triumphed over my reſentment, and I am ſtill weak enough to deſire another interview. Why, what can all this mean! This letter ſhould have been directed to me—

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Proceed, Sir, and the miſtery will ſoon vaniſh.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Tho' by ſeeing you again, I may poſſibly hazard the breaking off an advantageous match, with a man I deteſt. Hell and the furies! what is this? Does ſhe mean me? the crocodile of the Nile, and the ſhark of the Ganges! Had ſhe nobody to play off her monkey tricks upon, but me! Deteſt me!

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Compoſe your rage, good Governor, and finiſh the epiſtle.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Compoſe the devil, my Lord. Why I can't ſee a word more of it—I am ſtruck blind with paſſion—this comes of my falling in love, forſooth, and wanting to be married to a young girl, truly.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: You are cheaply off, Governor, at the expence only of a little laughing, and I think I have a right to my ſhare of that—Ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Cheaply off! now I think that, what between money and mortification, I have paid plaguy dear for my experiment—but I'll have my revenge, d'ye ſee, and ſhall go, this moment, in purſuit of it.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: I muſt ſtop you, Sir, 'till your paſſion has ſubſided a little, and then I will venture to truſt to your good nature.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Don't tell me of good nature, my Lord, ſhe has made my heart as hard as a rock.

div.stage: Enter a Servant, with a Letter to the Governor.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: The meſſenger waits for an anſwer, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: What's this! another billet-doux from the traitreſs!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: He's in a horrid paſſion, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Not without reaſon, I aſſure you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: (Reading.) I ſhall burſt with rage.— There never was ſuch a villainous proceeding. A raſcally coachmaker, a varniſhing Scoundrel, I think that's his name, my Lord, threatens to arreſt me for a debt I never contracted, becauſe the fellow thought I had been married, this morning, d'ye ſee.—It would have been a pretty ſort of incident, truly, to have happened on one's wedding-day.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: I apprehend, Governor, that this would not have been the only circumſtance of the kind you would have had to celebrate your nuptials, if you had married that lady.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: No, no, I did not fight Gentoos, Marattoes, Seapoys, and climates, d'ye ſee, to be bamboozled out of my money, at home.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: Except by a pretty woman, Governor.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Nor by her neither, when I find her falſe; and ſo Mr. Vaniſh may arreſt Mrs. Frankly, as ſoon as he pleaſes, for me.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: No, Sir, that debt I ſhall take upon myſelf, with pleaſure, for the happineſs I have received, through Mrs. Frankly's means, of knowing and eſteeming Lady Seaton as I ought. Beſides, a woman in diſtreſs, however incurred, is always intitled to the compaſſion and protection of a man of honour.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Nay, for that matter, my Lord, let me have but a little of my own way, d'ye ſee, and I can be as liberal as the beſt of you. I am paſſionate, but not ſevere; and ſo I forgive the injury, and ſhall diſcharge that debt; for methinks a man's mind and his means muſt be miſerably poor, indeed, who cannot afford to give, and forgive, too—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Nobly ſaid, Sir—I find you have brought over not only the wealth, but the humanity of the Eaſt Indians, along with you.

sp.speaker: Lord Sea.
sp.p: His taſtes and manners may be foreign, perhaps, Colonel, but his good-nature and generoſity are true Engliſh ſtaple. A Briton need never go a trafficking for principles.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Well, take me as I am—I have bought ſome wiſdom for myſelf, at preſent, for I ſhall not ſo readily believe that the women are in love with me, now, as they might have been, ſome thirty years ago. And ſo I ſhall think no more about a wife, for ſome time at leaſt, d'ye ſee; unleſs I ſhould renew my courtſhip to my old paſſion, Miſs Melville, here.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Take care of that, Governor, leſt you ſhould make the Colonel jealous.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Nay, if you are inclined to liſt with him, d'ye ſee, I'll keep clear of you; for 'tis dangerous meddling with other men's wives, now-a-days, I hear.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: If our modern marriages, Sir, were contracted upon the ſame principles I flatter myſelf ours is likely to be, a thorough love and eſteem for each other, we ſhould neither have ſo many libertine huſbands, or faithleſs wives.

q.l: True worth alone can form the charm that binds,
And rivet beauty's chains upon the mind.

div.head: EPILOGUE,
BY A FRIEND. Spoken by Mrs. MATTOCKS.
div.l: 'TIS very fine, indeed! all match'd I ſee,
All happy, all provided for, but me:
Blown up and ruin'd here—'tis a ſtrange notion,
You'll ſay, but I'm reſolv'd to croſs the ocean;
I'll e'en equip me for the Indian route;
Seaton and Ramſay join to fit me out:
Bull ſays he's ſure I need not then deſpair,
For Britiſh features bear a premium there.
Even this homely face would charm, they ſay,
Amongſt the copper beauties of Bombay;
And ſhe who in a croud would ſcarcely paſs
With us, would be a Venus, at Madraſs.
Pantheon, Opera, Playhouſe, Fantoccini,
Farewel—I'll go, and be a Nabobini:
Or, if that ſcheme, perchance, ſhould not ſucceed,
E'en wed a Seapoy chief, and mend the breed.
What if one's huſband is a little frightful,
Where every thing beſides is ſo delightful.
'Twill be ſo charming, on a ſummer's day,
For forty ſlaves to fan me as I lay,
Or on rich carpets free from noiſe and hurry,
Sit croſs-legg'd with my ſpouſe, and feaſt on Cury.
If I've a taſte for baubles, my good man,
Will load me with old China and Japan.
Diamonds on diamonds heap'd, and pearly rows,
For hair, ears, neck, and breaſt, perhaps my noſe:
No filthy hackneys there, ſo poor and mean,
Give me twelve Seapoys and a palanqui • .
I'll keep a little ſquadron at my call,
And make my firſt grand viſit in a ſhaul.
But muſt I leave my little Bull behind?
No, hang it, after all 'twould be unkind.
The fellow may be uſeful, he ſhall go;
For he can write, or underwrite, you know.
And many a worſe, I heard a ſweet bird ſing,
Goes out a writer, and comes home a king—

l.hi: A writer here is quite another thing!

div.l: So ſays our female author of to-night;
Poor ſoul, I hear ſhe's in a horrid fright,
She has ſent her little veſſel off to ſea,
And I am factor for the company—
Grant her, ye Critics, a few proſperous gales,
Let your applauſe but fill our ſwelling ſails;
Do you inſure her cargo ſafe and ſound,
And Bull ſhall underwrite five hundred pound.
The author for your paſſport trembling ſtands,
And hopes you'll grant it under all your hands.
